citation.article-title: Rearrangements of the species and genera of the phototrophic "purple nonsulfur bacteria."

p.s: Emendation of the genus Rhodospirillum Molisch 1907 (emend. van Niel 1944).

Type species: Rhodospirillum rubrum Molisch 1907. Other species: Rhodospirillum photometricum Molisch 1907, Rhodospirillum fulvum van Niel 1944, Rhodospirillum molischianum Giesberger 1947, Rhodospirillurn salexigens Drews 1982. Species removed from this genus: Rhodospirillum tenue Pfennig 1969.

Cells are spiral shaped, 0.5 to 1.5 μm wide, and motile by means of polar flagella and contain intracytoplasmic photosynthetic membranes as vesicles, lamellae, or stacks, but not as finger-like intrusions of the cytoplasmic membrane.
Cell shape and polar flagellation are the main common properties of this genus, which is in other aspects rather heterogeneous.

All species have different growth factor requirements. Rhodospirillum rubrum and Rhodospirillum salexigens grow well under aerobic conditions in the dark, whereas the other species are very sensitive to oxygen.

Three different types of intracytoplasmic membranes are present in the different species. Rhodospirillum rubrum and Rhodospirillum photometricum have a large type of cytochrome c2; the other species have a small type.
The major quinones are the same in Rhodospirillum fulvum and Rhodospirillum molischianum (ubiquinone and menaquinone with a side chain of nine isoprenoid units), but different in all other species.
Sulfate is reduced via 3'-phosphate adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate in Rhodospirillum rubrum and Rhodospirillum fulvum.
The heterogeneity of this genus may call for further separation into several genera.
However, this seems inappropriate until more strains of each species are studied in detail and more data become available to justify the establishment of new genera.
